page.title: 19HAZELSLADE WILDLIFE RESERVE
page.content: At Hazelslade there is a{nature reserve}with a stream, marshes, a pool, some deciduous woodland, some pasture land, a small meadow and a picnic area. It has developed naturally over the last thirty years and it is popular with local fishermen who catch tench, perch, roach, rudd, gudgeon and carp. The stream provides a suitable place for these fish to lay their eggs and sticklebacks and bullheads also live in it. Around the pool there is marshy land used by dragonflies, butterflies, herons and even snipe. The woodland provides cover for foxes and hedgehogs and homes for wrens, robins, blue tits and great tits. Jays, magpies and green woodpeckers can also be seen. Of course, many other species of wildlife inhabit this area and it is well used by local people.
